title: A Framework to build Games with a Purpose for Linked Data Refinement

author: Irene Celino, CEFRIEL, Politecnico di Milano

segmentation: So this is a joint work with my colleagues, Georgia, Gloria and Andrea in the context of a European project.
Name starts for also.
We now we had the wonderful panel yesterday about knowledge graphs and we are keeping talking about large scale link data, an management and link data.

Refinement is an open topic which is very well research in this community and usually the techniques to do link data refinement are based on machine learning or statistical learning and when it comes to that you need to train.
A machine and to train it you need to give them some true data, some some training set.
Ann to get that training set, you need to ask somebody to put it together so.
In the end, in order to train the machine, you still need humans, either expert or or generic audience to put it together.
Training set and this means in the linked data refinement case that you need people to solve task of linked data refinement.
So to get the information required to train.
System, so there are several strategies to collect data from users.
Um?
That come from crowdsourcing human computation fields and in the semantic web community.
They have been employed a lot for collecting triples, verifying triples, making ontology alignments, and every kind of stuff.
So these methods involve a user to solve some task, and in exchange or to motivate them to do that, they use different kinds of incentives from paying them.
Like in traditional micro working platforms like Mechanical Turk for example, to give him premium access to resources to train them.
So giving them knowledge or giving them recognition for their work and giving also fun incentives.
So we today I will talk about the last one.
So we are talking about games with a purpose which are a kind of gaming application in which people, players, players.
So they play in order to have fun, but as a collateral effect they are solving some tasks.
Um?

So the resource, since this paper is from the resources track, the resource that I'm presenting you today is a software framework that we name what enabler that allows you to build games with a purpose for link data refinement so that the players of the game solve your.
Linked data refinement tasks.
So the.
The the pipeline is that people play games in order to have fun as a collateral effect, they are executing task and or.
Those tasks can be used as training set for a machine learning algorithm so.
Why the need for such a software framework?
Because we think that there are a family of linked data refinement tasks that are quite common.
There are some game mechanics that can be reduced as well.
There are also aggregation algorithm to collect information from multiple users and making sense of them.
And last but not least to save efforts.
So developing an application from scratch is expensive.
So using a framework that is already there and thought to do that can be very very useful.
So.
Which kind of data link data refinement task are we talking to?
I'm talking about data linking, meaning drawing links between resources.
Well, I think I don't have to explain to this audience.
What links means that three cases that our that our framework supports our first creation of links.
So you have two resources and the predicate, and you draw a link between the resources and what you can do.
When you created or afterwards is that you can assign a score that is your confidence in the truth value of that link.
So the games will be used to create or update that kind of score on links.
So the second case of data linking is link ranking.
So you have two links to each link you.
Assign a score and you can make an ordering of course.
So to put those links in an order of recognize ability or popularity or stuff like that.

The third case is laying validation, so if you think that some link are true and some other fools, you can set a threshold, and when the score of the link overcome the threshold, the link can be considered true and all those links that have a score lower than the threshold are considered.
Fools.
So that's the main the basic.
Things that are supported so I will go very briefly through what is inside the framework.
There are more details in the paper and you of course can ask me more afterwards.
So first of all the game mechanics.
So as I said, this framework is designed to support a specific game mechanics that are very popular and can be reused.
So each game gives 1 task at a time and each action of the user is solving 1 task.

The games are usually double player games, so it means that each player is coupled with somebody else and they have to come to an agreement on what they what they think in order to get points in the game.
This is an incentive for the players to play fair and to give the right answer, let's say.
13 output agreement.
So the the agreement between players is on the their answer.
So there are different kind of game mechanics and this is based on output agreement.
Last but not least we are also injecting gold standard tasks so that our tasks of which we notice the right solution in order to check the reliability of players so that we avoid players just.
Playing randomly.
With respect to the aggregation, so the truth inference algorithm, each user player contribution is considered a single evidence on the truth or value of a link.
Those contributions are weighted with the reliability of what I was talking about before.
And we have implemented an incremental truth inference algorithm, which means that as soon as the score, for example overcomes the threshold, you don't ask the same.
You don't propose the same task to any other player, because the task is already sold.
This minimizes the number of players that are required to solve a task and also helps in identifying those tasks that are more difficult if the score.
Does not increase overtime.
It may means that the task is either too difficult or simply it's confusing and it's not to be solved anyway in the game.
So it's a.
Software framework, so how it is built?
So it's a very simple web application.
There is a database.
There are of course also all the structures for points, leaderboards, badges and everything that are related to.
Again, I wanted to point out those three tables that are the subject table, the object table, and the table.
That of course expressed the links with their with their score, and one.
The only, let's say requirement that we put on the data that must be fed in the game is that each.
Resource must have a sort of visualization, so if it's a text document, the text can be the visualization.
If it's a picture, the picture is by itself.
If it's, for example, a point of interest, maybe their coordinates are the way to visualize the object on on a map.
We also set up a number of predefined API both for Loading knew task in the system and for getting out the solution.
The aggregated solution and the triples directly out.
We also set up a predefined client application for the game.
We built it on traditional HTML5, angular JS and so on technologies, and we designed to also with a mobile first design so they can easily.
They are responsive and they can be easily used also from phones.
Last but not least, we are releasing all this framework under an Apache 2 license.
So I'll go through a number of applications that we built in the last few years.
On top of this framework, while building this framework, actually so the first one is named Indo Milando.
It's the purpose if is link ranking.
So in this case we were we are talking about cultural heritage assets in Lombardy region in Milano in this case and the game propose you the name.
Of an asset and four different pictures from 4 different assets and you have to guess which one is the right one.
So once you click on one of the picture you discover if you get it right or get it wrong.
So in this case we have all the links, the correct and the wrong links.
The links in this case is the asset is linked to the picture.
And by asking people we are trying to get which links are more recognizable.
This is because the pictures come from repository that was built for maintenance.
Reason of those cultural heritage assets, not for, for example, for advertising or for tourists.
And so we were asked to build the game in order to identify which are the most recognizable assets and which are the picture that best.
They picked those those assets.
So it's a pure game with a purpose.
There are points, badges, leaderboards, as in any game.
The game also showed an interesting educational collateral effect because people were learning to recognize assets and the link ranking is a result of the agreement.
So the more the people recognize it correctly, the more that score was.
I was, let's say, reliable, reliably recognized.
The second one is the Landcover validation game.
This was designed in order to validate links coming from two different actually machine learning algorithms.
So it is those two algorithms.
One was from the local institution and the regional institution and one from an international institution.
It was intended to.
Assign a land cover classification on the ground so you have this aerial picture.
With this small box and you have to classify which what land cover class applies to that box.
So we made it this game played during a conference.
The false forgie comfort.
It is a free open source software for just partial application so that.
Player was calling if he got one of the two classification and the goal was to discover which of the two classification was more accurate.
The last example I want to show you is a night night and it's a game to classify images taken on board of the International Space Station.
Those images are classified and then used in a pipeline for measuring the light pollution effect in cities.
So those photos are partially for cities from above, partially of Aurora, Borealis partially of astronauts themselves, and so on.
So people in the game had to.
Guess which of the class was was correct and it was also a bonus because you could then download the higher resolution picture from from the data website and the gain the player get points.
If he agrees with somebody else and we increase scores until we know which is the right classification.
So if you want to use it.
You can download it and you can also follow a tutorial.
So we we set up a full end to end tutorial to understand how the framework works internally and what it needs to be modified in order to fulfill your own.
Purpose.
And this actually happened, so I'm happy that Mateo is in the room because people from the University of Milano Bicocca actually took this framework and build their own game.
They're dealing with analogical reasoning, so they were trying to get example of analogies.
In this case is David Letterman is for the United States of America as Mr. X is for Italy and then you have 5 popular TV people in Italy and you have to find which.
And the nice thing I want to report is that they did it on their own.
I mean, we didn't almost make any effort in explaining their how to use the framework, so I think that I can say that the framework is easy, too easy to use, so.
To conclude, the framework is an open source framework to build games with a purpose.
It implements frequent cases of data linking.
It can be used to collect training sets for your machine learning algorithms, and it is thought to save you time and effort and to let you focus on your actual goal research goal.
And the next steps is to add additional cases data linking cases.
They are linked.
Data refinement cases apply to different domains and of course address all your requests, requirements, suggestion.
So thank you.
Thank you very much.
Thank you Dana for this nice talk.
It's time for questions and we over Paul.
I give you the microphone.
Very nice are two quick questions.

I think that few days if you if you have a clear idea of what you're.

If you want to apply different game mechanics.
Of course there are some coding to do.
I cannot estimate how much it takes because it really depends on how much you want to modify it.
I think that this mechanics covers.
90% of of the cases, at least in my own direct experience, thank you.
Or there's even two further questions.
Maybe make it quick.
We're almost done with our time.
Here are some maybe quick answer too.
I like the resource, but I was wondering what kind of related work existed.

I think you you said a bit about it, but.
Related work not sufficient already that that can be used, and I don't know.

If you want to develop a game.

Time we did it, the framework for ourselves 1st and then for the community.

Of course you can make it more interesting or more sexy from a user experience point of view, but you must make sure that this does not negatively impact the actual purpose that is collecting data.
